This study reports the synthesis and characterization of novel halogen-functionalized UiO-67 MOFs for CO₂ capture and conversion. Three mixed-linker Zr-UiO-67 MOFs, [Zr₆O₄(OH)₄(L₁L₂)₁₂], were synthesized, incorporating 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid (L₁) and halogen-substituted 4,4′-biphenyl dicarboxylic acids (L₂) with chlorine (MOF-1), bromine (MOF-2), or iodine (MOF-3). Comprehensive characterization confirmed successful MOF synthesis and halogen incorporation. Gas adsorption studies showed selective CO₂ adsorption over N₂ and CH₄. Critically, these MOFs exhibited exceptional catalytic activity for solvent-free CO₂ conversion to cyclic carbonates at ambient temperature and pressure. The Lewis acidic Zr centers facilitated heterogeneous catalysis of CO₂ fixation with epoxides, yielding cyclic carbonates with TBAB as a cocatalyst. High conversion (91–99 %) of epichlorohydrin to 4-(chloromethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one was achieved within 12 h at room temperature and 1 bar CO₂ pressure. A structure-activity relationship was established, revealing a direct correlation between halogen electronegativity and catalytic performance. CO₂ uptake and epoxide conversion rates increased across the halogen series from chlorine to iodine, attributed to the synergistic effect of the Lewis acidic Zr centers and the increasing polarizability of the halogen substituents. Moreover, the MOFs demonstrated robust recyclability, retaining substantial catalytic activity for at least five cycles. These findings underscore the potential of halogen-functionalized UiO-67 MOFs as promising candidates for sustainable CO₂ capture and utilization strategies. This increase in CO2 concentration leads to environmental problems such as global warming, climate change, and ocean acidification [3,4]. However, CO2 can also be seen as an abundant carbon-1 (C1) resource for the production of valuable chemical feedstocks [5,6]. In this context, CO2 capture and conversion (CCC) technologies offer a promising and sustainable way to mitigate the harmful effects of greenhouse gases [7–10]. Several techniques are employed for CO2 capture, including absorption (utilizing materials like ionic liquids [11,12], zeolites [13,14], and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [15,16]), adsorption (via MOF physisorption or chemisorption) [17], membrane gas separation [18], and storage in geological formations (saline, carbonate, or oceanic) [19,20]. Carbon capture and utilization (CCU) presents a promising mitigation strategy, wherein captured CO2 is transformed into valuable products such as urethanes, formic acid, dimethyl carbonates, and cyclic carbonates [21,22]. Cyclic carbonates synthesized from CO₂ and epoxides are of particular interest [23]. These five-membered cyclic carbonates exhibit significant industrial potential due to their diverse applications, including use as electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries, agricultural solutions, aprotic solvents in cosmetics, precursors in polymer synthesis, and intermediates in the production of acyclic carbonates, fine chemicals, and pharmaceuticals [24–27]. However, the development of effective catalysts for this CO2-to-cyclic carbonate conversion remains a key challenge [28]. Existing catalytic systems often require stringent reaction conditions and present difficulties in catalyst separation and regeneration. MOFs are promising materials for CO2 capture, separation, and conversion due to their high surface area, permanent porosity, excellent stability, and tunable functionalities [29]. These properties make MOFs applicable in various fields, including gas storage/separation, sensing, drug delivery, nonlinear optics, and heterogeneous catalysis [30,31]. Among MOFs, Zr-based frameworks (Zr-MOFs) are notable for their exceptional stability, ultrahigh surface area, and outstanding thermal and chemical resistance, which are advantageous for CO2 capture [32–34]. Lower connectivity Zr-MOFs are particularly beneficial for CO2 conversion due to increased space for mesoporous formation, facilitating larger molecule diffusion, and high densities of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, crucial for CO2 conversion reactions [35]. UiO-67, an octahedral Zr-based MOF, exemplifies this with its ditopic carboxylate ligands and stable Zr6 clusters, forming a structure with distinct octahedral and tetrahedral cages [36]. This study investigates the synthesis of halogen-functionalized UiO-67 MOFs by incorporating halogen-substituted biphenyl linkers into the robust Zr6 cluster framework. The rationale behind this approach is to capitalize on the inherent advantages of the UiO-67 structure while exploring the potential for novel functionalities imparted by halogen decoration [37,38]. Three novel porous mixed-linker Zr-UiO-67 MOFs, denoted [Zr6O4(OH)4(L1L2)12], were synthesized, where L1 represents 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxilic acid, and L2 represents 2-chloro-4,4’-biphenyl-dicarboxilic acid (MOF-1), 2-bromo-4,4’-biphenyl-dicarboxilic acid (MOF-2), or 2-iodo-4,4’-biphenyl-dicarboxilic acid (MOF-3). These materials were comprehensively characterized using powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and infrared (IR) spectroscopy. Adsorption experiments revealed a preference for CO2 over N2 and CH4 at 273 K, under pressures of 100 and 275 kPa. Furthermore, the synergistic effect of Lewis acidic Zr centers and halogen functionalities within the MOF structure facilitated efficient CO2 conversion to cyclic carbonates under environmentally benign conditions (solvent-free, ambient temperature and pressure). A systematic analysis revealed a direct correlation between CO2 fixation efficiency and halogen electronegativity, with increasing CO2 uptake and epoxide conversion rates observed across the halogen series from chlorine to iodine by increasing polarizability. The MOFs also exhibited excellent recyclability, retaining catalytic activity for at least five cycles without substantial performance degradation. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Characterization Three novel 2-halo-4,4′-biphenyl dicarboxylic acid ligands, specifically the chloro (H₂L1), bromo (H₂L2), and iodo (H₂L3) derivatives, were synthesized and characterized (see Supplementary Information, Figures S1-S3). MOFs-1-3 were subsequently synthesized via a solvothermal reaction at 120 °C for 24 h. This synthesis involved combining zirconium tetrachloride (ZrCl₄) with mixed carboxylate ligands, comprising 2,2′-bipyridine-4,4′-dicarboxylate and one of the aforementioned 2-halo-4,4′-biphenyl dicarboxylic acids, in N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF) as solvent and glacial acetic acid as a modulator (Scheme 1). The resulting MOFs were characterized and their phase purity confirmed using FE-SEM, PXRD, FT-IR, TGA, and XPS spectroscopies. FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. 1 a) of MOFs-1-3 revealed characteristic asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the coordinated carboxylate groups (COO⁻) within the ranges of 1590–1610 cm⁻¹ and 1471 cm⁻¹, respectively [39]. Additionally, the Zr–O stretching vibrations of the cluster (–Zr–O) were observed between 600 and 800 cm⁻¹ [40]. The presence of non-coordinated DMF was indicated by C–O stretching vibrations around 1645–1654 cm⁻¹. Phase purity and crystallinity were assessed via PXRD analysis (Fig. 1b). The PXRD patterns of MOFs-1-3 demonstrated congruence with the parent UiO-67 structure, exhibiting comparable crystallinity across all materials. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K (Fig. 2 a) revealed differing nitrogen uptake capacities among the investigated MOFs. UiO-67 demonstrated a superior adsorption capacity compared to MOFs-1-3, exhibiting a BET surface area of 1293 m² g⁻¹ at a relative pressure (p/p°) of 0.99. In contrast, MOFs-1-3 exhibited BET surface areas of 987.8, 943.4, and 854.7 m² g⁻¹ at the same relative pressure. Despite their lower surface areas, MOFs 1-3 possessed substantial mesoporosity and notable thermal and chemical stabilities. TGA of MOFs-1-3, conducted under a nitrogen atmosphere from 30 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min⁻¹, showed similar decomposition profiles for both parent and modified MOFs. An initial weight loss of approximately 13 % between 30 and 480 °C, attributed to the desorption of non-coordinated solvent molecules, was observed. Framework collapse, indicated by a significant mass loss, occurred at approximately 500 °C (Fig. 2b). SEM analysis was employed to characterize the morphology of the synthesized MOF derivatives. As illustrated in Fig. 3 b–d, MOFs-1-3 exhibited an octahedral morphology with an average particle size of approximately 200 nm, consistent with the morphology observed for the UiO-67 MOF (Fig. 3a). XPS experiment was utilized to investigate the surface chemical composition and electronic states of the metallic constituents within the MOF clusters (Fig. 4 a). The XPS spectra revealed characteristic peaks consistent with the presence of zirconium (Zr), oxygen (O), nitrogen (N), and carbon (C), which are typical elements found in MOF structures. The binding energies observed for these elements were consistent with established values. Specifically, the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 core levels were identified at 183 and 185.5 eV, respectively (Fig. 4b) [41]. Similarly, peaks corresponding to the O 1s, N 1s, and C 1s core levels were observed at approximately 530 eV, 395 eV, and 280 eV, respectively [42]. Furthermore, halogen signals were detected, which chlorine 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 signals were located at 200.8 eV and 202.5 eV, respectively (Fig. 4c, top). Bromine 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 signals were observed in the 70.8 eV and 71.9 eV region, respectively (Fig. 4c, middle). Iodine 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 signals were observed at 620 eV and 637.1 eV, respectively (Fig. 4c, bottom) [43]. Acidity and basicity properties of the MOF-3 were characterized by CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD, as presented in Fig. 5 .The CO2-TPD analysis of MOF-3, as depicted in Fig. 5a, displayed three desorption peaks. The peak in the 25–200 °C region suggests the presence of weak and moderately basic sites, likely due to unsaturated O2– anions in the Zr–O-Zr or Zr–O– configurations of the Z6 nodes, as reported in prior studies [44,45]. The peaks within the 200–350 °C and 350–650 °C intervals are indicative of CO2 release from the breakdown of acetic acid and the BPyDC/BPDC-Halogen linkers, respectively. The NH3-TPD profile for MOF-3 (Fig. 5b) showed desorption peaks below 250 °C, which are attributed to weak to moderate acidic sites, specifically hydroxyl groups (Brönsted) and exposed Zr4+ ions (Lewis) in the Zr6 nodes [46,47]. 2.2 CO2 fixation with epoxides The synthesized zirconium-based MOFs exhibit a strong affinity for carbon dioxide adsorption [48–50]. Furthermore, their insolubility in common solvents, high thermal stability, and the presence of Lewis acidic Zr(IV) sites suggest their potential as heterogeneous catalysts [51,52]. Consequently, their catalytic activity in the fixation of carbon dioxide with various epoxides, yielding industrially relevant cyclic carbonates, was investigated [53–55]. As illustrated in Scheme 2 , MOFs-1-3 utilize multiple activation modes to enhance both CO2 capture and fixation. The Zr-clusters function as Lewis acid centers, activating the epoxides, while the nitrogen-donor sites within the bipyridine linkers act as Lewis base sites, facilitating CO2 activation [56]. In a representative experiment, a mixture comprising epichlorohydrin (2 mmol), tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) (0.25 mmol), and the Zr-MOF catalysts (1-3) (0.2 mol %) was placed in a sealed vessel. Following CO2 purging, the reaction mixture was stirred under a CO2 atmosphere at room temperature for a specified duration. Upon completion, the solid catalyst was recovered via centrifugation, and the crude products were analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy using mesitylene as an internal standard (Figure S4). In this study, epichlorohydrin (ECH) served as a model epoxide to evaluate the catalytic activity of three MOFs. Under identical reaction conditions (temperature and time), MOF-3 exhibited superior performance, yielding a 99 % product conversion, compared to 94 % and 91 % for MOFs 1 and 2, respectively (Table 1 , entries 1–3). Subsequently, the reaction kinetics were investigated over a 12-h period, employing the optimized conditions of 0.2 mol% catalyst loading at 25 °C (Table 1, entries 4–9). While all MOFs demonstrated a substantial yield increase within the initial 4 h, the subsequent 8 h showed diminished gains. MOF-1 afforded the lowest yields at 4 and 8 h (75 % and 88 %, respectively; Table 1, entries 4–5). MOF-2 provided moderately improved yields of 77 % and 89 % at the same time points (Table 1, entries 6–7). Notably, MOF-3 catalyzed the reaction to near-quantitative yields of 85 % and 95 % after 4 and 8 h, respectively (Table 1, entries 8–9), confirming its superior catalytic activity. The optimization of catalyst loading for CO₂ fixation was investigated by varying the MOF-3 catalyst concentration from 0.1 to 0.5 mol% under established experimental parameters. A catalyst loading of 0.1 mol% yielded approximately 78 % of ECH (Table S1, entry 1). A significant increase in product yield to 99 % was observed upon raising the catalyst concentration to 0.2 mol% (Table S1, entry 2). However, further increasing the catalyst amount to 0.5 mol% did not result in any further improvement in product yield, which remained at 99 % (Table S1, entry 3). These findings suggest an optimal catalyst loading of 0.2 mol%. Concurrently, the co-catalyst TBAB concentration was optimized. Increasing the TBAB amount from 0.1 to 0.3 mmol led to an increase in product yield from 83 % to 99 %; further increases in TBAB concentration did not affect the yield (Table S1, entries 2,4–5). Therefore, a TBAB concentration of 0.2 mmol at a reaction temperature of 25 °C was determined to be optimal. A reduction in pressure resulted in a decrease in efficiency to 87 % (Table S1, entry 6). Conversely, increasing the pressure to 1.5 and 2 bar did not significantly alter the efficiency (Table S1, entries 7–8). Similarly, variations in reaction temperature within the tested range did not induce substantial changes in efficiency (Table S1, entries 9–11). Control experiments established the necessity of both catalyst and co-catalyst for efficient CO2 fixation. In the absence of both, no product formation was observed (Table S1, entry 12). The combination of ZrCl4 catalyst and TBAB co-catalyst yielded a 56 % product yield (Table S1, entry 13), while TBAB alone as catalyst afforded only a 21 % yield (Table S1, entry 14), demonstrating the synergistic effect of ZrCl4 and TBAB. Furthermore, reactions catalyzed by ligands H2L1-H2L3 resulted in yields between 20–25 % (Table S1, entries 15–17). The catalytic activity of MOFs-1-3 over time is depicted in Fig. 6 a. Substrate scope was investigated using MOF-3 under optimized conditions (Table 2 ). Aliphatic epoxides, specifically propylene oxide and 1,2-butylene oxide, yielded high conversions of 98 % and 94 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 1–2). However, the larger aliphatic epoxide, butyl glycidyl ether, exhibited a reduced yield of 55 % (Table 2, entry 3). Similarly, aromatic epoxides such as, styrene oxide and glycidyl phenyl ether were converted to their corresponding carbonates with yields of 53 % and 67 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 4–5). The sterically hindered cyclic cyclohexene oxide showed significantly lower reactivity, yielding only 12 % conversion (Table 2, entry 6). These findings suggest that substrate size plays a crucial role, with smaller substrates exhibiting higher reactivity due to facile diffusion and access to the active sites within the Zr-MOF pores, consistent with observations reported for other MOF catalysts [56]. A leaching test, wherein the catalyst was removed after two hours, confirmed the absence of catalytic activity in the filtrate (Fig. 6b), suggesting minimal leaching from active sites. The heterogeneous nature of MOF-3 was investigated through catalyst recyclability tests employing the cycloaddition of ECH under optimized conditions. Following each reaction cycle, the catalyst was recovered via centrifugation, subjected to methanol washes, and thermally activated at 90 °C prior to subsequent use. Recyclability experiments indicated consistent catalytic activity for at least four cycles, with no significant decrease observed within the first three cycles (Fig. 6c). A slight reduction in cyclic carbonate yield was noted in the subsequent two cycles. Post-reaction characterization of the recovered catalyst via PXRD demonstrated structural integrity after five catalytic cycles (Fig. 6d). Furthermore, SEM, XPS, IR, and TGA experiments were demonstrated structural stability of this MOF after five catalytic cycles (Figure S11). 2.3 Gas sorption studies Prior to gas sorption analyses, the synthesized MOFs were activated. This involved a 36-h immersion in MeOH, followed by vacuum heating at 120 °C to remove non-coordinated DMF molecules and residual solvent. Structural characterization revealed that the MOF pore walls are functionalized with carboxylate oxygen and nitrogen moieties, as well as halogen atoms (chlorine, bromine, and iodine) directed into the pore space. These functionalities are anticipated to enhance gas adsorption performance [57,58]. Consequently, CO2 adsorption isotherms were measured at 195, 273, and 298 K up to a pressure of 100 kPa (Fig. 7 a−c). All MOFs exhibited Type I adsorption behavior. At 195 K, the CO2 uptakes were 2.34 mmol/g (55.7 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-1, 5.30 mmol/g (100.9 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-2, and 7.89 mmol/g (132.3 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-3, corresponding to BET surface areas of 756, 685, and 423 m²/g, respectively. Decreasing the temperature to 273 K resulted in CO2 uptakes of 1.44 mmol/g (32.2 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-1, 2.74 mmol/g (57.6 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-2, and 3.35 mmol/g (71.6 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-3. At 298 K, the uptakes further decreased to 0.89 mmol/g (21.7 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-1, 2.01 mmol/g (45.1 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-2, and 2.53 mmol/g (56.5 cm³ g⁻¹ STP) for MOF-3 (Fig. 7a−c). The observed higher CO2 uptake and surface areas are attributed to the synergistic effect of the halogen and carboxylate functionalities present in the ligands. The superior adsorption capacity of MOF-3 is likely due to halogen bonding interactions between CO2 and the halogen atoms. The increased polarizability of the iodo- group in MOF-3 facilitates stronger CO2…I interactions compared to the less polarizable bromo- and chloro- groups in MOF-2 and MOF-1, respectively, which is consistent with the observed adsorption trends (Fig. 7) [59,60]. As previously noted, this enhanced CO2 adsorption in MOF-3 correlates with improved CO2 fixation efficiency. These results suggest that strategic modification of MOF ligands and cluster functionalities can be employed to optimize catalytic CO2 fixation reactions [61,62]. The isosteric heats (Qst) of CO2 adsorption are calculated based on the adsorption data collected at 195 and 298 K. As shown in Table S2, the Qst values are 17.96−49.6 for MOF-1, 39.95−114.09 for MOF-2, and 50.24–158.67 Kj.mol for MOF-3, respectively. The trend in the Qst values is clearly in accordance with the uptake amounts of the order: MOF-3> MOF-2> MOF-1. It is clear that the CO2 uptake and isosteric heats of MOF-3 is higher than MOFs-1 and -2, which can be attributed to the stronger interactions between the CO2 and iodo group [63]. Having observed promising CO2 adsorption with MOFs 1-3, comparative high-pressure (100–275 kPa) adsorption studies were conducted at 273 K using CO2, CH4, and N2 (Fig. 7d-f). As shown in Fig. 7, CO2 adsorption capacities for MOF-1 and MOF-2 increased from 1.52 to 1.98 mmol/g and 2.01 to 2.48 mmol/g, respectively, over the pressure range studied. MOF-3 exhibited a similar trend, with uptake increasing from 2.78 to 3.02 mmol/g. These CO2 adsorption isotherms suggest that pore saturation occurs at lower pressures, limiting further CO2 uptake at higher pressures. In contrast, N2 and CH4 adsorption at the same temperature and pressure were significantly lower across all MOFs (Fig. 7d-f). Specifically, CH4 uptake ranged from 0.2 to 0.8 mmol/g, while N2 uptake ranged from 0.07 to 0.15 mmol/g. These findings highlight the potential of these MOFs for CO2 capture and separation, attributable to the selective interaction between CO2 and the halogen and amine functional groups present in the MOFs [64]. The observed enhancement in CO2 uptake within the three functionalized MOFs necessitated an evaluation of their CO2 adsorption selectivity over CH4 and N2. To assess their separation efficacy, Ideal Adsorbed Solution Theory (IAST) calculations were performed [65,66]. Optimal fitting of the experimental pure-component adsorption isotherms for CO2, CH4, and N2 was achieved using the dual-site Langmuir model (R2>0.9995; Figure S12). These fitted parameters were subsequently employed to predict IAST selectivities for 10:90 CO2/CH4 and 15:85 CO2/N2 mixtures across a range of bulk pressures (Figure S13). The CO2/CH4 selectivities were determined to be 3.2–3.4 (MOF-1), 6.3–6.4 (MOF-2), and 8.9–9.1 (MOF-3), while CO2/N2 selectivities were 9.4–9.9 (MOF-1), 18.6–22.9 (MOF-2), and 31.5–43.1 (MOF-3). The superior CO2 adsorption enthalpies and selectivities observed in MOF-3, relative to MOF-1 and MOF-2, are attributed to stronger interactions between the functionalized framework and CO2 molecules. The catalytic performance of MOF-3 in the coupling reaction of CO2 with ECH, using TBAB as a co-catalyst, was evaluated and compared with that of other reported MOF catalysts. The results, summarized in Table 3 , demonstrate that MOF-3 achieved higher or comparable yields under mild reaction conditions. Specifically, MOF-3 exhibited superior performance in terms of conversion, reaction conditions, and CO2 pressure compared to UiO-67-based MOFs and metal-cyclam-based Zr/Hf MOFs (VPI-100, PCN-222(Mn), and MOF-801(PZDC-NO2)), which required higher temperatures and yielded lower conversions. Scheme 3 illustrates a proposed mechanism for the MOF-3-catalyzed CO₂ fixation with epoxides, based on prior research [72]. The reaction is initiated by the activation of the epoxide through coordination to the Lewis acidic dinuclear Zr(IV) center within the MOF. Subsequently, the bromide anion (Br⁻) from the cocatalyst, TBAB, attacks the less sterically hindered carbon of the epoxide, inducing ring opening and generating a haloalkoxide intermediate. The iodo group within the MOF is posited to activate CO₂ via polarization, thereby promoting nucleophilic attack by the haloalkoxide on the CO₂ carbon. This leads to the formation of an alkyl carboxylate. Finally, cyclization occurs, regenerating both the MOF-3 catalyst and TBAB for subsequent catalytic cycles, yielding the cyclic carbonate product. 3 Conclusion In conclusion, this study successfully synthesized and characterized a series of novel halogen-functionalized UiO-67 MOFs (MOF-1, MOF-2, and MOF-3) as promising candidates for CO₂ capture and conversion. The incorporation of halogen substituents (Cl, Br, and I) onto the UiO-67 framework was achieved through a mixed-linker approach, resulting in materials with tailored properties. These MOFs exhibited selective CO₂ adsorption over N₂ and CH₄, and, more importantly, demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity for the solvent-free conversion of CO₂ to cyclic carbonates under mild conditions. The observed structure-activity relationship highlighted the crucial role of halogen electronegativity and polarizability in enhancing CO₂ uptake and epoxide conversion, with iodine-functionalized MOF-3 exhibiting the highest performance. The high conversion of ECH to its corresponding cyclic carbonate, coupled with the robust recyclability of the catalysts, underscores their potential for practical applications. These findings demonstrate the viability of halogen-functionalized UiO-67 MOFs as effective and sustainable materials for CO₂ capture and utilization, contributing to the development of greener chemical processes. coredata.dc:description: This study reports the synthesis and characterization of novel halogen-functionalized UiO-67 MOFs for CO₂ capture and conversion. Three mixed-linker Zr-UiO-67 MOFs, [Zr₆O₄(OH)₄(L₁L₂)₁₂], were synthesized, incorporating 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid (L₁) and halogen-substituted 4,4′-biphenyl dicarboxylic acids (L₂) with chlorine (MOF-1), bromine (MOF-2), or iodine (MOF-3). Comprehensive characterization confirmed successful MOF synthesis and halogen incorporation. Gas adsorption studies showed selective CO₂ adsorption over N₂ and CH₄. Critically, these MOFs exhibited exceptional catalytic activity for solvent-free CO₂ conversion to cyclic carbonates at ambient temperature and pressure. The Lewis acidic Zr centers facilitated heterogeneous catalysis of CO₂ fixation with epoxides, yielding cyclic carbonates with TBAB as a cocatalyst. High conversion (91–99 %) of epichlorohydrin to 4-(chloromethyl)-1,3-dioxolan-2-one was achieved within 12 h at room temperature and 1 bar CO₂ pressure. A structure-activity relationship was established, revealing a direct correlation between halogen electronegativity and catalytic performance. CO₂ uptake and epoxide conversion rates increased across the halogen series from chlorine to iodine, attributed to the synergistic effect of the Lewis acidic Zr centers and the increasing polarizability of the halogen substituents. Moreover, the MOFs demonstrated robust recyclability, retaining substantial catalytic activity for at least five cycles. These findings underscore the potential of halogen-functionalized UiO-67 MOFs as promising candidates for sustainable CO₂ capture and utilization strategies.
